required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Study: The Effects of Medical Music on Anxiety in Patients With ILD
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Study: The Effects of Medical Music on Anxiety in Patients With Interstitial Lung Disease

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

clinical_study.source: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

brief_summary.textblock: This is uncontrolled, interventional feasibility study for determining the effects medical music on anxiety levels in subjects with ILD. Enrolled subjects will be asked to complete questionnaires and undergo physiologic measurements prior to listening to medical music. The music intervention will be for approximately 30 minutes. Post intervention questionnaires and physiologic measurements will be done.

detailed_description.textblock:
The Medical Music intervention includes playlists that contains songs specifically designed, recorded, and optimized through the provisionally-patented methods, to treat their co-morbid anxiety. The duration of the medical music playlist is 30 minutes.
Enrolled subjects will be asked to complete questionnaires to assess anxiety, a questionnaire related to their music preferences, and undergo physiological measurements (vital signs, galvanic skin response, and heart rate variability) before and after the intervention.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This is an uncontrolled, interventional pilot study to determine feasibility

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility of using a medical music intervention as a treatment for anxiety in subjects with ILD, as measured by descriptive evaluation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in State Anxiety Inventory scores before and after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The State-Trait Anxiety Inventory Questionnaire is a psychological inventory based on a 4-point Likert scale and consists of 40 questions on a self-report basis. It measures two types of anxiety - state anxiety, or anxiety about an event, and trait anxiety, or anxiety level as a personal characteristic.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Visual Analogue Scale scores for Anxiety and Distress (VAS-A) before and after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The VAS-A is a psychometric response scale to measure respondents level of anxiety and stress by indicating a position along a continuous line between two end-points ("not at all" to "extremely").

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Borg Dyspnea Scale scores before and after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The Borg Dyspnea Scale measures perceived dyspnea on a scale from 0 to 10.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in heart rate variability before and after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Heart rate variability will be measured before and after intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in galvanic skin response before and after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Galvanic skin response will be measured before and after intervention

arm_group.description: All subjects will undergo the medical music intervention.

intervention.description: Enrolled subjects will undergo 30 minutes of medical music listening

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Men and women age 50 to 80 years old
- Diagnosis of definite or probable interstitial lung disease (ILD)
- Willingness to participate and sign consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are deaf
- Inability to provide informed consent
- Pregnant women

patient_data.ipd_description: De-identified data will be available to the public upon request in a timely fashion.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: De-identified data will be available to the public upon request in a timely fashion.
